Author: jl777c#5810
Content: @Biz @Decker @dukeleto @Alright

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: @dukeleto @jl777c About XMR forks and BLUR. I didn't have time yet to deep-in inside XMR, due election preparation tasks, but seems XMR forks is totally different from Bitcoin-based coins and it's will very hard and impressive work if we can get it compatible with Iguana. From KMD side seems all remains the same (mean, how the nota tx is created, signing process and others). But from XMR side, currently it looks for me as a "deep jungle" or "other planet". First, XMR uses  RingCT (Ring Confidential Transactions) protocol, instead of well-known bitcoin protocol. It means (for me) that i totally don't know how to construct, sign and verify tx in XMR-based coin network. But one thing i know (it's good), seems it's possible to create and sign multisig tx with - prepare_multisig, make_multisig, finalize_multisig daemon RPC's (but this is also, still "deep jungle", bcz i'm  quickly read about it, but didn't tried). Also, all bitcoin forks, including kmd and zcash is utxo based. And iguana work guessed work with utxos ... but in XMR seems things are different, if i'm don't wrong with it: "Monero doesn‚Äôt have an UTXO set (the whole blockchain is the TXO set)" ... so, for now, i'm totally confused how XMR work and how dPOW should work in XMR. Hope, it's only for now, and future learning will clear something for me.

Author: jl777c#5810
Content:
there are two main issues:
1. how to store the notarization data (2 hashes and height)
2. how to create a transaction that all the nodes in the network can recognize as a notarization

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: in bitcoin protocol we put the notarization data in opreturn data

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: for the recognition, we have the participating notaries all sign the same transaction that has the notarization data. that allows all nodes to verify the signatures are from the valid pubkeys and then they can see if the notarization data matches what they already have locally

Author: Biz#0842
Content: ah, this solution is actually fairly easy.  just not very well known that this is possible.  We have pay-to-scripthash type transactions as well.   The issue that @dukeleto is running into is probably the result of PoW hashes only being included in block hashes implicitly.  However, that's somewhat irrelevant to the ability for notarization nodes to be able to recognize a specific transaction.. within each transaction that occurs, we have a "tx_extra" field which is publicly viewable from the blockchain and is the same field that pools use for pool nonce.

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: how many bytes is it?

Author: Biz#0842
Content: This field is specifically left open, and not verified for content by other nodes, for the purpose of adding functionalities like this.

Author: Biz#0842
Content: it is the remainder of each block, until the block is full.  I will have to check to get you a number for sure... how many do we need?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: 80 is enough for the notarization data

Author: Biz#0842
Content: yes there is plenty of room for that and then some.

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: but I was thinking that if it has enough space for 13 signatures, we can put the signatures from the notaries there too

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: then we dont need to figure out how to determine which notary signed which input

Author: Biz#0842
Content: hmmm may have to get creative there.  I would just add a specific op_code for ntz txns.  Leading byte of the data in each field of transaction extra are parsed, which signal to the node parsing them how to handle the data that follows, and a size of bytes is included when the size isn't implied by the opcode/type of data itself

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: what would be easiest to integrate would be to put the rawtxbytes of a normal bitcoin notarization in there. that way the notarizer can just use the existing code to validate it. we then need to have some way of getting this tx confirmed

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: a notarization tx is about 2kb

Author: Biz#0842
Content: can you provide an explorer link to the precise formatting and length that would be necessary to support?

Author: Biz#0842
Content: or just a raw tx i suppose would be more helpful

Author: Biz#0842
Content: I could include this data in a transaction extra, and test it on our explorer, so we can know right away.

Author: Biz#0842
Content: basically, if the length fits, it will work.

Author: Biz#0842
Content: and as I said, this field is technically in the extranonce of a transaction's metadata, it gets seen by every node that comes in contact with it, but is never verified for content.

Author: Biz#0842
Content: I am not sure what you mean by getting the tx confirmed, but we could take that data, hash it with sha256, and give it a specific opcode as well or something as well if the data size is too large

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: https://kmdexplorer.ru/tx/0ab85c7b846d61bdc7add7fe87aa88ff698af3797b79105bafecb79fd1e2794f

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: had to split it in two parts, that is from RFOX chain but the data size wont change by more than a few bytes (length of chain name)

Author: Biz#0842
Content: ok

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: bitcoin does not support a 13 of 64 multisig

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: so I made a standard transaction with 13 inputs and the daemon compares it against the 64 valid pubkeys

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: this achieves the 13of64 multisig in a much more compact rawtx

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: even without the signatures, just the redeemscript would have been 2kb

Author: Decker#3767
Content: https://bitcointalk.org/index.php?topic=1605144.msg32538076#msg32538076 - here is my explanation of nota tx, may be this also will helpful here.

Author: Biz#0842
Content: ah. okay. that makes  sense.  there are not really any documents to speak of for monero's multisignature. rbrunner made some as he/she is the dev behind integrating multisig messaging for them

Author: Biz#0842
Content: https://taiga.getmonero.org/project/rbrunner7-really-simple-multisig-transactions/wiki/extra-transaction-data

Author: Biz#0842
Content: that is the most comprehensive documentation that exists, probably.

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: if it can support 13 of 64 multisig, that would be one way to skin this cat

Author: Biz#0842
Content: thanks @Decker

Author: Biz#0842
Content: I am pretty sure that it would be possible actually.

Author: Biz#0842
Content: AFAICT there is support for N/N, M/N, and N-1/N schemes

Author: Decker#3767
Content: i'm read that monero itself supports N / N and N-1 / N multisig ... to sign participants should exchange private view and public spend keys ...

Author: Decker#3767
Content: but, all of this is a still "deep jungle" for me ((

Author: Biz#0842
Content: I do not think exchanging private viewkeys is smart for security purposes

Author: Biz#0842
Content: they are deterministic from private spendkeys

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: encapsulating the entire normal raw tx feels the easiest way to get the notarization onchain

Author: Biz#0842
Content: i agree.

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: assuming that works

Author: Biz#0842
Content: let me give it a go

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: then the issue is who is posting these tx onchain

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: it really doesnt matter as the contents are signed

Author: Biz#0842
Content: just logistically, yes i understand

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: but unless we have a way to make sure it gets onchain just once, we end up with a veriblock spam situation or nobody posting

Author: Biz#0842
Content: yeah, that kind of spam is a big part of why i didn't feel their system was the one for us

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: maybe some sort of deterministically based order and the notaries monitor to make sure it goes out, so there might be a delay of a few blocks if one some of the 13 signers are not posting it

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: yes, that works. (notarizationheight % 13)

Author: Biz#0842
Content: that sounds doable

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: that is the notary that should post the tx

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: if he doesnt, then the next block the next in line does

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: and since they just signed the notarization, we should get 99.9% success on the first one

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: just an untimely shutdown would need to have the second in line

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: but we have all 13 monitoring to make sure it is sent

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: @blackjok3r

Author: Biz#0842
Content: yes that sounds good as long as we have all 13 waiting in line as you say. I also dont think it would pose an issue if we had say 3/10 send it

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: i dont like 3x inefficiencies, actually i dont like 10% inefficiencies...

Author: Biz#0842
Content: I think maybe relying on a waiting queue that has a single point of failure could maybe cause problems, especially if latency is the only thing responsible... could end up with some nodes sending more than one anyway in that event though

Author: Biz#0842
Content: you are right. probably best the way you say

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: its simple and if the mempool is also there we can prevent duplicates

Author: Biz#0842
Content: sure.  with only 13 nodes sending the transaction, duplicates aren't a huge concern.

Author: Biz#0842
Content: let me get to embedding this data, and i'll be right back

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: @Decker I think this method will require the least changes in the notarizer. Basically pretend BLUR is a normal coin, get a notarized tx fully signed. then instead of sending it out, embed it in a tx in the extra data and set the first height to broadcast

Author: Biz#0842
Content: we can include up to 2 times the median block limit: which is  `Median block size limit: 292.97 kB`.. compiling now, and then i'll send a tester

Author: Biz#0842
Content: so it should work either way. but lets make sure

Author: Biz#0842
Content: I think our blockchain would run into issues economically with bloat, honestly, before we hit a limit

Author: Biz#0842
Content: But ring sigs are sizeable too

Author: Biz#0842
Content: So, yes it will work. All that would need done is the extra field would need  extended beyond the 255 bytes of padding currently allotted

Author: Biz#0842
Content: Or we could add a separate field within the extra with a different opcode.  we will be changing consensus rules already for DPoW, extending this field to include additional op codes, even one a specific one for one for each notary node would be trivial to implement. Currently, the field is limited to 255 bytes. But blocks have much more room

Author: Biz#0842
Content: The size of the a given field in an tx extra (not the whole extra) is limited by the ability to encode the number 255 into the bytes that follows the opcode

Author: Biz#0842
Content: So we include a field field with the notation of 0xFA and include ten of those, to achieve 2.5kb necessary in a block, or we could do 13 iterations of a smaller field etc.

Author: Biz#0842
Content: This is the same way that pubkeys are read from transactions currently
